messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:56): http://flashisdead.tumblr.com/
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:59): Google finance doesn't look like it uses any magical aspects of flash, but maybe I'm missing advanced features
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:00): Analytics seems similar.  It looks like it would work fine with canvas and/or SVG.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:01): Chatroulette is fair until <device> works.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:01): Dunno about the others.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:01): Homestar runner is fair enough, flash is made for animation. But it's not that it's impossible, there just aren't any tools to do it the HTML5 way
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:01): "let's see your html5 do this" is a nice slogan
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:01): Sound mixing has been requested several times, so that's fair too
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:02): Image editors... seems like canvas could handle that fine
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:04): wants to see html5 do those things
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:04): Important difference between html5 can do x, and someone has actually done the work to create a html5 tool doing x
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:04): Wait until IE < 9 has, let's say, under 5% market share.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:05): As long as flash has 98% or whatever, most people will be happy using existing tools
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:05): Or at least grudgingly accepting :P
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:06): Not if they know HTML+CSS but not Flash.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:06): They have to learn HTML+CSS+JS anyway, so if they no longer have any reason to use Flash, they'll stick with a unified setup.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:06): That's our major advantage.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:06): I mean the users
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:06): As long as there exist tools that solve their problems, there's reduced demand for creating equivalent html5 tools
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:07): If I want to say my page is in english in HTML5, where should I place the attributes that dictate this?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:07): It's the authors who will control the switch.  Users aren't going to know or care whether you use HTML5 or Flash, on the whole.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:07): Existing tools have to be maintained, maybe rewritten occasionally.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:07): Authors respond to demand, though
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:07): <html lang="en-US"> ?  <meta http-equiv="content-language" content="en">
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:07): They'll fade over time.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:07): Both?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:07): Authors will adopt HTML5 over Flash because it makes their lives easier or improves the quality of their product, not because their users explicitly demand it.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:07): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: just <html lang>
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:07): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, <html lang> is the better bet.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:08): So <html en-US></html> ?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:08): Again, not direct demand
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:08): Oh!
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:08): <html lang="en-US">, got it.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:11): So <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"> became <meta charset="UTF-8">?  If so, does this only affect http-equiv="content-type", or any other http-equiv?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:12): Only content-type
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:13): It's the result of supporting <meta http-equiv=content-type content=text/html; charset=utf-8>

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:14): So meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" became meta charset="UTF-8" and meta http-equiv="content-language" content="en-US" became html lang="en-US" ... cool.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:14): No, lang appeared on its own
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:14): The header content-language and @lang are different in subtle and confusing ways
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:15): (Otherwise we might've been saved the thread about it...)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:30): I've spent more than two hours reading all my spec mail.  :(
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:30): But I'm finally done.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:45): Question about writing out Element Attributes; should they always be arranged alphabetically?  href="@page-url@" title="@go-to@ @page-title@",  content="@site-author@" name="author", or do they have an arrangement written somewhere?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:47): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, what to me?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:47): Element attributes are logically unordered.  Use whatever order you like.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:48): I'm not sure what your question is, exactly.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:48): Okay, you answered my  question, I didn't know if I'm supposed to write id="myId" class="myclassname" or if class="myclassname" id="myId" was just as correct, sorting alphabetically.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:51): Thanks, I was wondering if there was a logical order.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:51): Because if element attributes are logically unordered, we could order them alphabetically, like we do with CSS properties.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:51): That doesn't sound logical
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:51): You'd end up writing <a class="foo" href="bar"> etc
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:52): when clearly it should be <a href...>
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:52): Any order is fine.
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (22:53): i never alphabetize my css
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:54): The only CSS that's alphabetical is the indexes :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:56): I line up my DVDs in order of increasing height of the age rating icon on the spine, but even I don't alphabetise CSS
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:57): What's up with meta content="IE=8;chrome=1" http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" not validating?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:57): X-UA-Compatible is a non-standard extension.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:57): You don't alphabetize your css properties?  Huh.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:57): So it's not supposed to validate as standard.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:57): Also, will that value actually work?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:58): It seems like you could just leave out the IE part, unless you specifically don't want your site to work in IE9 for some reason.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (22:59): Well, no the issue is that IE runs in IE7 mode on intranets, so I just learned from 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): That's true.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): If it's an intranet, you could just reconfigure them all, couldn't you?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): I'm told that's easy on Windows intranets.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:00): Sure.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:01): So, writing <body><div id="document" role="document"></div></body> is the worst idea ever and standards-breaking, or valid and at my descretion?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:05): It seems to be technically valid as far as HTML5 is concerned, unless I missed the part that bans it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:05): It seems pointless, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:05): <body> has implicit document semantics.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:07): Right, but I think this could be useful when you're in a modx, Facebook, or another portal based page where you have a dock or a chat application that sits aside the div#document.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:07): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132: If you use x-ua-compatible, you should use "IE=edge" so that it always uses the latest version

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:08): Are you testing the effect that role is having here in an actual UA that supports role, or just speculatively adding markup in case maybe for someone it would be better than not having the markup?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:08): (so that you benefit from improved performance and standardiness in future versions)
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (23:09): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: yah i was thinking the same.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:10): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, good call.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:10): Or so you contribute to IE=edge becoming frozen as IE8 because too many people use it and depend on quirks~
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:10): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, both.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:11): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, don't do the latter, ever.  Do not add features you can't test.  They'll probably make things worse.  UAs can deal with you ignoring their existence, they can't deal with you giving them explicit instructions that turn out to make no sense because you didn't test them.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:11): I've learned this the hard way.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:11): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, I have corrected this.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:11): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, what tools do you recommend I use to test these?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:13): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, I don't know.  But if you aren't testing, don't use the feature, period.  You *will* do it wrong and your site *will* break when someone finally does implement the feature.  Guaranteed.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:13): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: He should use IE=edge and not depend on quirks
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:13): I take the red pill, 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:13): and should test in various browsers and in IE betas
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:14): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, what?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:14): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, http://izanbardprince.files.wordpress.com/2008/08/red-pill-or-blue-pill.jpg
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:14): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Yeah. The problem is that if enough other people don't, his site will still be affected.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:15): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: He'll be affected less than if he uses IE=8
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:16): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, I've seen The Matrix.  I have no idea what you mean in context.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:17): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, I mean that I'm risky and I wanna see what happens --- but really if no tool exists to evaluate this then I can theorize.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:18): The spec says I can, and it makes sense to me this way, so the only reason I could provide against it would be that someone implements it differently.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:18): No, that is an absolutely terrible idea.  Drop it immediately.  You're doing a disservice to yourself and your users and the web as a whole.  Deploying a feature that hasn't yet been implemented is almost guaranteed to break, and that either 1) hurts your users if their site breaks, or (worse) 2) hurts browsers because they get complaints from users that the site breaks in the new version, since the new version implements the feature you're u
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:18): sing brokenly.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:19): What will happen is that either you will misunderstand the spec somehow, or else the implementation will have some quirk you weren't expecting.  I have had this happen to me *multiple* times.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:19): When I learned that Opera supposed datalist, I added support to MediaWiki and tested in Opera -- only to find out that actually there was a slight quirk I never would have predicted that made it behave worse than the non-datalist functionality.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:20): When I learned that Opera supported attributes like pattern on inputs, I added pattern to lots of inputs, and tested.  It turned out that if a password field fails a constraint, it will print the value of the password field in plaintext.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:21): In both cases, if I had blindly added the feature without testing it in any actual user-agent, it would have caused significant *harm* to users when Opera added the feature.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:21): You could test, what do I have to test?  JAWS?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:22): In another case, when I was young and stupid and didn't yet realize the absolute necessity of testing, I added a handheld stylesheet to MediaWiki without having any mobile UA handy, figuring something was better than nothing.  This actually broke Opera Mobile (or Mini or something), to the point that they went to the effort to dig up wikitech-l and ask there for us to remove our handheld stylesheet because it was broken.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:22): If you care about blind users, then yes, absolutely test in JAWS.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:22): Just because I'm pushing back doesn't mean I'm disregarding what you're saying, just developing with you.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:22): Add whatever features demonstrably make your users' experience better.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:23): Do not add features that don't do anything and might or might not do something in the future just because you can.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:24): Right, change for change sake.  I'm trying to take advantage of meaning to enforce existing standards.  For instance, most folks need a <div id="wrapper" /> or something like that on their site.  Something that wraps all the pages content and separates it from another application on the page.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:24): And that lead me to look into the role document and application, which seemed to fit perfectly in this paradigm, and describes itself as such.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:24): And goes as far as to say this scope doesn't apply to the whole page, but part of the page.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:25): So I thought, let's take this great thing and mix it in with the existing need for a wrapper, consolidating the two.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:25): Semantics for semantics' sake is just as bad.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:26): Keep this in mind: if you use role nowhere at all, your page will be like 99.9% of pages out there.  Screen readers for the blind will be able to handle that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:26): So it will work fine.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:26): What about consolidation by means of semantics?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:26): If you use role *incorrectly*, your site will work *worse*.  It might become unusable, even.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:27): The gains are not worth the risk from any kind of practical standpoint.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:27): 70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132, that's a string of buzzwords, not an actual reason.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:27): An example of a reason to use role="something or other" would be "so JAWS does X instead of Y".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:27): Where X is better than Y.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:27): As we get to know each other more, you'll learn I'm not a buzzword guy.

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:30): I think there's a balance, and sometimes you have to edge past the 99.9% paradigm, get the test results, learn, and develop.  Then progress is made.  And it looks like I have good counsel in this room to remind me how dangerous it can be to force users to adopt my suggestions :)

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:33): I've added a whole lot of HTML5 features to MediaWiki (thus to eventually be deployed on Wikipedia), and I have always followed this maxim: only add something if I can clearly spell out a user-visible benefit.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:35): remembers he needs to work out something about validation of HTML5 with non-HTML5 doctype, ugh
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:38): Hixie: are you around?
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:39): I like that 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, and thanks for taking the time to chat about it with me.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:39): You can look at <http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/HTML5> for a list of features we (I) have implemented.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:39): I have to go now, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:40): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, it might be enabled on Wikipedia soon, but I've been saying that for like six months.  :P
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (23:41): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: just use http://html5.validator.nu/

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:41): Code review has been very slow lately, and since I'm not a sysadmin I can't sneak in my changes without a full deployment, but 1.16rc1 has been released, and a deployment of 1.16 to Wikimedia is supposed to follow before 1.16 final.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:41): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, I can, but other people use validator.w3.org.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (23:43): if (ua == 'validator') echo '<!doctype html><title></title>'; else { ...

70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:43): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, yea the long term elements will be an interesting piece of tackle, since many yesterday mobile browsers won't work with html5 elements, even with the "shiv" javascript hack.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:43): I look forward to seeing how that goes, have fun.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:44): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, . . . that is so evil that I never even thought of it, but it just might work.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:44): will keep it in mind.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:45): Won't work on Wikipedia, though, Squid caching.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:03): is removing <head> conforming in XHTML5?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:04): hmm I see, it's not trying to produce XHTML5
